text:
This doll can perform tiny sit-ups thanks
to a material in its waist that bends when
it adsorbs certain chemical vapors.

But the researchers who made the material
have bigger plans for it than making a doll
do calisthenics.

They hope to improve the mechanical properties
of a class of materials called covalent organic frameworks,
or COFs.

COFs are porous crystals that could be used
for applications like water purification and

gas separation, and as energy storage materials
in batteries and capacitors.
COFs are related to metal-organic frameworks.

But unlike MOFs, which consist of metal ions
connected by organic linker molecules,

COFs contain only organic building blocks held
together by strong covalent bonds.

COF’s have shown promise for a variety of
applications, but they’re difficult to work

with because they are very brittle and tend
to form insoluble powders rather than large

films or sheets that could be useful for purifying
water or separating gases.

So researchers have explored a variety of
ways to improve their mechanical properties,

such as tweaking reaction conditions to force
crystals to grow larger and interweaving molecular
threads to form flexible COF structures.

Now, researchers at Nankai University, Tianjin
University, and the University of South Florida

have made strong, flexible COF films by combining
the COF with polymers.

They took a polymer strand containing polyethylene
glycol units and linked it between the building
blocks of an existing COF, known as COF-42.

The final material, which the researchers
have named polyCOF, combines the porosity

of COFs with the strength and flexibility
of polymers.
And the polyCOF boasts another ability.

It bends when it adsorbs vapors of organic
solvents, like ethanol.

When removed from the vapors, the material
flattens.

The researchers demonstrated how this mechanical
ability could be used to curl up and lift
small objects.

COFs designer James Wuest at the University
of Montreal noted that although the work is

related to what others in the field have already
accomplished in studying the properties of

COFs, he thinks the incorporation of polymers
is a promising new direction.
